description:
Quercus robur, commonly known as the English oak or common oak, is a deciduous tree species native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Fagaceae family and is one of the most widely distributed and ecologically important oak species in its native range.

The Quercus robur tree can grow to a height of 20-40 meters and has a broad, rounded crown. The bark is typically gray and deeply fissured, providing a distinctive appearance. The leaves are lobed, with a distinctive shape that is characteristic of the species. The acorns produced by the tree are an important food source for various wildlife species.

Quercus robur is known for its longevity, with some individuals living for several centuries. It is an important timber tree, providing high-quality wood for a variety of uses, including furniture, construction, and shipbuilding. The species also plays a crucial role in the ecosystem, providing habitat and food for a diverse range of organisms, including insects, birds, and small mammals.

Quercus robur is considered a keystone species in many European forest ecosystems, contributing to the overall biodiversity and ecological function of these habitats. Its ecological and economic importance has led to its widespread cultivation and conservation efforts in many parts of its native range.
